caption: On Saturday a plane crashes shortly after take off in South Sudan's capital Juba, killing the four South Sudanese passengers and the three Russian crew members.

result.explanation: The image shows the aftermath of a plane crash.  People are present near the wreckage. The caption mentions a crash in South Sudan's capital Juba, with casualties including South Sudanese passengers and Russian crew members. While the image doesn't explicitly confirm the nationalities of the people shown or the exact location, the visual context is consistent with the caption's description of a plane crash. The lack of clear identification of nationalities and precise location reduces the confidence score.

candidates.title: South Sudan plane crash: Dozens killed near Juba airport
candidates.content:
A cargo plane has crashed on take-off near the international airport in South Sudan's capital Juba, killing at least 36 people.
Two people were pulled from the wreckage alive but one of them later died, leaving a young girl as the only survivor, the Red Cross said.
The Antonov An-12 plane was heading to Paloch, Upper Nile State, and crashed 800m (half a mile) from the runway.
In a statement, Ukraine-based Antonov said the plane had not been airworthy.
It said the plane, which was built in 1971, "was is no state to fly because it failed to undergo timely technical servicing... that should have included work on extending its resources and exploitation timeframe", AFP news agency reported.
South Sudan authorities warned that the death toll could rise as the debris was cleared.
The plane crashed into a farming community on an island on the White Nile River but so far all the victims recovered were from the aircraft, the Red Cross said.
candidates.description: A cargo plane crashes near the international airport in South Sudan's capital Juba, killing at least 36 people.

candidates.title: South Sudan plane crash baby 'conscious' in Juba
candidates.content:
A 14-month old girl who survived Wednesday's plane crash in South Sudan's capital, Juba, is now conscious, doctors say.
The girl is being treated at the city's teaching hospital and is able to recognise relatives, journalist Philip Mabior from Juba's Eye Radio reports.
At least 36 people died after the plane crashed on take-off near Juba airport.
The cause of the crash remains unclear but the manufacturer said the cargo plane was not airworthy.
The UN peacekeeping mission in South Sudan has sent divers to search the nearby White Nile for bodies, and also for the black box recorders.
The Antonov An-12 plane, operated by local company Allied Services Limited was heading to Paloch, Upper Nile State, and came down 800m (half a mile) from the runway.
It crashed into a farming community on an island on the White Nile, but it is not clear how many of the victims and survivors were passengers and how many were on the ground.
It is not clear if the 14-month old girl is the only survivor.
She was one of two people taken alive from the wreckage on Wednesday, the other is reported to have died later.
However, Philip Mabior said another person who survived the crash was also being treated in hospital.
candidates.description: A 14-month old girl who survived Wednesday's plane crash in South Sudan is now conscious in hospital and able to recognise relatives, doctors say.

result.explanation: The news caption mentions 7 deaths (4 passengers + 3 crew members) and a crash on Saturday. The provided sources mention at least 36 deaths in a crash on Wednesday.  There is a discrepancy in the number of deaths, the day of the week the crash occurred, and the nationalities of the victims. The sources do not specify the number of passengers vs. crew.  Therefore, the claim is not supported.
result.supporting_points: Source 1 and Source 2 both report a plane crash near Juba airport on Wednesday, resulting in at least 36 deaths.  Neither source specifies the exact number of passengers and crew members.

final_result.explanation: The news caption states that a plane crashed in Juba, South Sudan on Saturday, killing four South Sudanese passengers and three Russian crew members.  Internal validation acknowledges the image depicts a plane crash and that the caption is consistent with the visual context, although it notes the lack of explicit confirmation regarding nationalities or precise location reduces confidence.  External validation, however, reveals significant discrepancies. Multiple sources indicate a plane crash near Juba airport on Wednesday, resulting in at least 36 deaths, contradicting the caption's details on the number of casualties (7 vs. at least 36), the day of the week (Saturday vs. Wednesday), and the nationalities of the victims. The sources do not offer a breakdown of passengers and crew.  The internal validation only assesses textual coherence with visual context; it doesn't verify factual accuracy. The external check directly contradicts the caption's factual claims. Due to the substantial discrepancies between the caption and externally verifiable information, the caption is considered out of context. The confidence score is low (3) because of the conflicting information and lack of corroborating evidence supporting the caption's specifics.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal validation finds the caption consistent with the image but lacks strong evidence, while external validation reveals significant discrepancies regarding the number of deaths, day of the week, and nationalities, deeming the caption out of context.
